name: q15_4
solnTex:
Let $f(z)= rac{1}{z^4+1}$. Then $f$ is an even function and the integral we want is
\[ rac{1}{2}\int_\mathbb{R}f(z)dz.\]
The denominator of $f$ is $z^4-1$ which has roots where $z^4=-1=e^{\pi i}$. The four solutions to this are $z=e^{i	heta}$ for $	heta= rac{\pi}{4}, rac{3\pi}{4}, rac{5\pi}{4}, rac{7\pi}{4}$. Let $\alpha=e^{i rac{\pi}{4}}$. Then $z^4-1=(z-\alpha)(z-i\alpha)(z+\alpha)(z+i\alpha)$. 
Let $c(t)=Re^{it}$ for $R>1$ and $t\in[0,\pi]$ and let $p(t)=t$ for $t\in[-R,R]$. Let $\gamma$ be the concatenation of the two. Then Cauchy's integral formula applied to $\gamma$ and $f$ gives
\[\int_\gamma f(z)dz=\int_\gamma rac{1}{(z-\alpha)(z-i\alpha)(z+\alpha)(z+i\alpha)}dz=\int_\gamma rac{ rac{1}{(z-i\alpha)(z+\alpha)(z+i\alpha)}}{z-\alpha}dz+\int_\gamma rac{ rac{1}{(z-\alpha)(z+\alpha)(z+i\alpha)}}{z-i\alpha}dz\]
\[=2\pi i\left( rac{1}{(\alpha-i\alpha)(\alpha+\alpha)(\alpha+i\alpha)}+ rac{1}{(i\alpha-\alpha)(i\alpha+\alpha)(i\alpha+i\alpha)}ight)\]
\[=2\pi i\left( rac{1}{4\alpha^3}+ rac{1}{-4i\alpha^3}ight)= rac{\pi}{2}(i-1)\alpha^{-3}= rac{\pi}{2}\sqrt{2}e^{ rac{3\pi}{4}i}e^{- rac{3\pi}{4}i}= rac{\pi}{\sqrt 2}.\]
Estimating the integral over $c$ as $R	o\infty$ gives
\[\left|\int_cf(z)dzight|\leq\int_c|f(z)||dz|=\int_c\left| rac{1}{z^4+1}ight||dz|\leq\int_0^\pi rac{1}{R^4-1}dt= rac{R\pi}{R^4-1}	o0.\]
As $R	o\infty, p	o\mathbb{R}$ so our desired integral is
\[ rac{1}{2}\int_\mathbb{R}f(z)dz= rac{\pi}{2\sqrt 2}.\]
